hints.content:
A $2\times2$ matrix can be used as a transformation in the coordinate plane. We can write a point $(p_x,p_y)$ as a column vector.  

$\qquad \vec{p} = 
\left[ \begin{array} {cc}
p_x \\
p_y \\
\end{array} \right] $

If we multiply this by the transformation matrix, $T$, we can find the coordinates of the new point, $p'$. 

$\qquad T \cdot \vec{p} = \vec{p} \ '$ 

In this case, we find that  

$\qquad \left[ \begin{array} {cc}
-1 & 0 \\
0 & 1 \\
\end{array} \right] 
\left[ \begin{array} {cc}
p_x \\
p_y \\
\end{array} \right] 
=
\left[ \begin{array} {cc}
-p_x \\
p_y \\
\end{array} \right] 
$.

*This transformation represents a reflection across the $x$-axis.* **False** 

*This transformation represents a reflection across the $y$-axis.* **True**  

Since the matrix changes the sign of the $x$-coordinate of every point, it represents a reflection across the $y$-axis.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/19a9f511e57b078bfc7df198c5f8f36c9a543b19.png)

*This transformation preserves angles.* **True** 

A reflection across the $y$-axis preserves angles.

*This transformation maintains the distance between points.* **True** 

A reflection across the $y$-axis is a rigid transformation, so it maintains the distance between points.

*This transformation can map the point $(0,1)$ to $(0,-1)$.* **False**  

Applying the transformation, we can see that it cannot be used to map point $(0,1)$ to $(0,-1)$.  

$ \qquad \left[ \begin{array} {cc}
-1 & 0 \\
0 & 1 \\
\end{array} \right] 
\left[ \begin{array} {cc}
0\\
1 \end{array} \right] 
=
\left[ \begin{array} {cc}
0  \\
1 \end{array} \right] 
\neq
\left[ \begin{array} {cc}
0  \\
-1 \end{array} \right] 
$

The following statements are true:  

 - This transformation maintains the distance between points.

 - This transformation preserves angles.

 - This transformation represents a reflection across the $y$-axis.

question.content:
**Select all statements which are true about the given transformation equation.**  

$\qquad T \cdot \vec{p} = \left[ \begin{array}{cc}
-1 & 0 \\
0 & 1 
\end{array} \right] \vec{p} = \vec{p} \, '$

[[â˜ƒ radio 1]]

choices.content: This transformation maintains the distance between points.
This transformation represents a reflection across the $x$-axis.
This transformation represents a reflection across the $y$-axis.
This transformation can map the point $(0,1)$ to $(0,-1)$.
